Fig. 1 N2O conversion over the Co3O4(CP)(×) and xF-Co3O4 catalysts (x = 0 (+), 1.5 (△), 2.0 (□), 2.5 (◊), 3.0 (○), 3.5 (▲),5.0 (●)) of 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XRD diffraction patterns of the Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 SEM photos of Co3O4(CP) (A), 0F-Co3O4 (B), 3.0F-Co3O4 (C), and EDS analysis of 3.0F-Co3O4 (D). Fig 3 Fig. 4 TEM and HR-TEM images of Co3O4(CP) (A, a1, a2), 0F-Co3O4 (B, b1, b2) and 3.0F-Co3O4 (C, c1, c2). Fig 4 Fig 5 Textural structure of 3.0F-Co3O4 observed from TEM. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (A) Co2p and (B) O1s XPS spectra for Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 O2-TPD profiles of the Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Lnk as a function of 1/T for the reaction over the Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts. Fig 8 Fig. 9 N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Co3O4 (A) and Co3O4(CP) (B) catalysts for the feed gas 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar (+); with 5 vol% O2 (△), 2 vol% H2O (□), 100 ppmv NO (◊), 5 vol% O2 + 100 ppmv NO (○) and 5 vol% O2 + 100 ppmv NO + 2 vol% H2O (▲) at diverse temperature, respectively. Test conditions: catalysts of 0.2 g, Ar balanced, total gas flow of 50 ml min−1, GHSV=20,000 h−1. Fig 9 Fig. 10 N2O conversion changed with time on stream over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst at 350 °C and 400 °C when some of impurity gases were injected in or cut off from the feed stream of 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar with 20,000 h−1. The preparation of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with “Yardang Landform” structure and its performance for catalyzing N2O decomposition Haibiao Yu Funding acquisition Conceptualization Methodology Visualization Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Xingkun Qi Conceptualization Methodology Software Investigation Visualization Writing – review & editing Supervision Xinwei Du Methodology Supervision Project administration Yan Pan Writing – review & editing Investigation Xiaogeng Feng Data curation Formal analysis Weijun Shan Methodology Software Ying Xiong Funding acquisition Conceptualization Project administration Methodology Supervision ⁎ College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China College of Chemistry Liaoning University Shenyang 110036 PR China College of Chemistry, Liaoning University, Shenyang 110036, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. In this work, the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was synthesized by sol-gel method with the assistance of F127 and used for eliminating the N2O pollution from nitric acid plants. Research indicated that the presence of F127 in the preparation process endowed the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with unique “Yardang Landform” microstructure, which possessed a rich number of “edges and corners”. The unique microstructure enables the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst to mainly expose highly active (400) and (511) crystal planes. Based on this unique microstructure, the surface active site density for 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was 7.62 µmol g−1 m2, which was about 9 times that of Co3O4(CP) catalyst prepared by traditional co-precipitation method. In addition, the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst demonstrated high catalytic activity and stability for the reaction in presence of impurity gases. For example, the catalyst can maintain a conversion of more than 60% for N2O at least 10 h in the feed stream of 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar with 5 vol% O2, 100 ppmv NO and 2 vol% H2O at 400 °C and GHSV = 20,000 h−1. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N2O decomposition Yardang Landform microstructure F127 Co3O4 Impurity gases Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrous oxide (N2O) is considered as the third potent greenhouse gas, as its global warming potential is 310 times that of carbon dioxide and 21 times that of methane. Even worse, it can continually consume stratospheric ozone, due to its strong atmospheric stability [1,2]. Many human activities, such as chemical processes and automobile exhaust, are the main sources of N2O pollution, and the total emission of N2O is increasing year by year [3,4]. Hence, it is crucial to realize the effective elimination of N2O pollution. At present, the commonly used N2O elimination technologies are high temperature thermal decomposition [5,6], selective catalytic reduction [7,8] and direct catalytic decomposition [9,10]. Amongst them, direct catalytic N2O decomposition is regarded as the most promising N2O elimination technology because it is economical, efficient and environmentally friendly. For direct catalytic N2O decomposition catalysts, Co3O4 has been found to be one of the most effective active components, and the corresponding cobalt-based composite metal oxide catalyst has attracted the attention of most researchers [11–21]. In general, one or more elements, such as alkali metals [11,18,21], alkaline earth metals [17,20], transition metals [13–15,19] or other large radius and rare earth metals [12,16,21], usually employed as additives into Co3O4 by co-precipitation, impregnation, hydrothermal or sol-gel method to improve catalytic performance of the catalyst. The electron donating and structural modification effect of additives to Co3O4 play a vital role in improving catalyst performance for N2O decomposition. Liu et al. [22] synthesized Sm-doped Co3O4 catalyst for direct catalysing N2O decomposition by sol-gel method. They found that the Sm species enhanced the oxygen vacancies amount, reducibility and oxygen desorption capacity of the Co3O4 catalyst. Hence, the performance of N2O decomposition on the Co3O4 catalyst significantly increased. Yu and coworkers [12] prepared series Pb x Co catalysts by simple co-precipitation method and found that the introduction of Pb greatly increased active sites on the catalyst and significantly weakened the Co-O bond. In addition to adding additives, building special microstructures and controlling the exposure of highly active crystal planes by specific preparation methods can also essentially improve the catalytic performance of Co3O4 for decomposing N2O. As early as 2016, Stelmachowski et al. [23] tried to prepare Co3O4 catalyst with different morphologies by precipitation, hydrothermal and supercritical solution methods, respectively. They found that the morphological structure of Co3O4 affected the surface electronic properties, and the surface electronic properties were closely related to the performance of N2O decomposition. By 2017, Duan and coworkers [24] explored the influence of Co3O4 morphology on its exposed crystal planes and catalytic performance. They found that the nanorod-like Co3O4 mainly exposes the (220) crystal plane, the irregular-shaped Co3O4 crystallites mainly expose the (111) and (040) crystal planes, the large particle size Co3O4 only exposes the (040) crystal plane, and the spherical particle-shaped Co3O4 exposes (220) and (311) crystal planes. Combining with the catalytic N2O decomposition test, they believe that the structure of the catalyst and the exposed crystal planes show very remarkable effect on the catalytic activity. In the same year, impregnation and glycerol-assisted impregnation methods were employed to prepare Co3O4/α-Al2O3 catalyst for N2O decomposition by Gudyka and coworkers [25]. They confirmed that the (100) crystal plane was the highly active crystal plane corresponding to the catalytic decomposition of N2O by Co3O4. The exposure of (100) crystal plane was beneficial to maintain the catalytic stability of Co3O4 in the simulated nitric acid plants exhaust atmosphere. Similarly, Li et al. [26] prepared Co3O4 spinels with various morphologies, including nanocubes (NC-Co3O4), nanosheets (NS-Co3O4), nanorods (NR-Co3O4), and nanopolyhedra (NPL-Co3O4). The catalytic activity of NC-Co3O4 predominant exposing the (001) crystal plane was higher than that of NS-Co3O4 and NR-Co3O4 mainly exhibiting the (110) crystal plane. The oxygen vacancies were more readily formed on (001) crystal plane which requires less activation energy (only 30 kJ mol−1) than that of (110) crystal plane. In fact, the relationship between the morphology, active crystal planes exposure of the catalyst particle on the nanometre scale and its reaction performance had been extensively studied in the past few decades for different catalytic reactions [27–29]. Representatively, Li and Shen summarized the interactions between the rod-shaped oxides and the metal nanoparticles in metal-oxide catalyst systems, and discussed how nanoscale anisotropic morphology catalyst particles affected the reaction performance by selectively exposing the required planes [27]. Cao et al. also discussed the size and shape effects of catalyst particles on catalytic activity and selectivity of reactions performed at solid-gas or solid-liquid interfaces in detail by summarizing a large number of literature [28]. Obviously, controlling the catalyst morphology and selectively exposing the desired highly active crystal planes are expected to direct the development of highly efficient nano catalysts for a long time in the future. F127 (PEO106PPO70PEO106, Mav=12,600) is an amphiphilic triblock copolymer, which is often used as a soft template to synthesize different materials due to its superior properties [30]. The so-called amphiphilic triblock copolymer is a kind of surfactant, which can form micelles after adding a certain amount in water, which has a certain influence on the structure and morphology of the catalyst during the synthesis process. In this paper, F127 was selected as the surfactant to prepare Co3O4 catalyst with special “Yardang Landform” structure by a simple sol-gel method. The optimal amount of F127 was discussed and the effect of preparation method on the surface properties of the catalyst was also explored. Most importantly, the catalytic performance of the optimum catalyst in catalysing N2O decomposition under simulated real nitric plant tail gases was thoroughly investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Raw materials Co(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Pluronic F127 (PEO106PPO70PEO106, Mav=12,600) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Nitric acid (HNO3), Na2CO3 were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All the chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Preparation xF-Co3O4 and Co3O4(CP) The xF-Co3O4 catalysts were generally prepared by sol-gel method in the following procedures. Desired amounts of Pluronic F127 was added dropwise to a mixed solution containing 2.4 g concentrated nitric acid and 17 g distilled water at room temperature under stirring until the solution became clear and transparent. Then 5 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O was added to the above mixed solution and stirred continuously at 90 °C until a transparent gel was obtained. The obtained gel was dried at 120 °C overnight, followed by calcination at muffle furnace in the process of 150 °C for 1 h, 250 °C for 0.5 h and 400 °C for 2 h under the static air. According to the weight (gram) of Pluronic F127 added to the mixed solution, the catalysts were labelled as xF-Co3O4, where x represents 0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0, 3.5 and 5.0 g. For comparison, the pure Co3O4 catalyst was synthesized by the traditional co-precipitation method [31], which was labelled as Co3O4(CP) in order to distinguish. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The XRD, Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, SEM, TEM, XPS, FT-IR and O2-TPD characterizations of the catalysts were the same as those described in the literatures [12,31]. 2.4 Activity measurement and kinetics study The N2O decomposition reaction over the catalyst was carried out in the tubular quartz fixed-bed reactor (Φ = 6 × 1 mm) with 0.200 g prepared catalyst (40–60 mesh, density of the catalyst bed: 1.327 g ml−1). Before testing, the catalyst needed to be pretreated at 400 °C in Ar with the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 20,000 h−1 (50 ml min−1) for 30 min. Subsequently, a reaction gas consisting of 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar (or adding some impurity gases, such as 5 vol% O2, 2 vol% H2O or 100 ppmv NO) was introduced into the reactor. The reaction system was shown in the Fig. S1. The reaction temperature was between 250 and 400 °C, with 50 °C as a step, which was measured by a thermocouple next to the catalyst layer. At every temperature step during measurement, the reaction lasted at least 30 min to obtain the real activity data. The reaction exhaust gas was injected through a six-port valve, and the residual N2O concentration was detected in real time by a Varian GC3800 gas chromatograph (stationary phase Porapak Q: length 3 m, inside diameter 2.1 mm, thermal conductivity detector, high purity Ar as carrier gas). The corresponding N2O conversion was calculated according to the following formula: (1) N 2 O conversion ( % ) = [ N 2 O ] in − [ N 2 O ] out [ N 2 O ] in × 100 ( % ) In the above equations, [N2O]in and [N2O]out represent the total concentration of N2O at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively. In addition, kinetic parameters of the reaction over the specific catalysts, such as reaction rate (r), rate constant (k), specific activation energy (E a) and turn over frequency (TOF) were calculated by evaluating from our integral reaction results. In this process, the N2O concentrations at each definite catalyst bed layer were calculated, according to the reaction order that was confirmed to be the first order. The calculated equations were consistent with the description in our previous study [12]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of F127 on the catalytic performance of xF-Co3O4 First, the effect of the addition amount of surfactant F127 on the catalytic performance of xF-Co3O4 for N2O decomposition (2000 ppmv N2O/Ar, 50 ml min−1) was tested and compared with that of Co3O4(CP) prepared by co-precipitation. As shown in the Fig. 1 , the addition of F127 during the preparation process greatly improved the catalytic activity of the xF-Co3O4 catalyst compared with that of Co3O4(CP). For example, the N2O conversion over the Co3O4(CP) catalyst was only 24.3% at 350 °C, which was much lower than that over xF-Co3O4 catalysts (x = 1.5–5.0). When 1.5 g F127 was used during the preparation process of the sol-gel method, the N2O conversion over the prepared 1.5F-Co3O4 catalyst at 350 °C was 63.2%. With the amount of F127 increasing from 1.5 g to 5.0 g, the N2O conversion exhibited a firstly increasing and then slightly declining trend, and the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst showed the most optimal catalytic activity. The N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was ∼80%, which was about 3.3 times that of the Co3O4(CP) catalyst. In addition, it is worth noting that the 0F-Co3O4 catalyst prepared by the sol-gel method without adding any surfactant F127 exhibited the worst catalytic performance, only 9.5% N2O conversion was obtained. It means that the surfactant F127 plays a vital role in improving catalytic performance, rather than the preparation method. 3.2 Textural structure characterization of the catalysts Based on the discussion in Section 3.1, Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 were selected to explore the influence of surfactant F127 on the textural structure of Co3O4 catalysts. Fig. 2 presented the XRD diffraction patterns of the Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0-Co3O4 catalysts. From the figure, it can be clearly seen that all the diffraction peaks of the three catalysts can be attributed to the spinel Co3O4 structure (JCPDS 43-1003) [12,15]. It indicated that the sol-gel method used F127 as surfactant did not change the crystal plane of Co3O4. Moreover, the average crystallite size of three catalysts was roughly calculated by Scherrer equation according to the half width of the peak at 2θ = 36.84° for rough reference, and the results were listed in Table 1 . The average crystallite size of Co3O4 in 3.0F-Co3O4, 0F-Co3O4 and Co3O4(CP) catalyst was about 27, 30 and 50 nm, respectively. It is worth stating that these data do not have much practical significance, as 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with complex nano-structure. The changes in the microstructure of the catalyst need to be visually determined by electron microscope. Correspondingly, the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the three catalysts were obtained according to the experimental data of nitrogen adsorption and desorption. As shown in the Table 1, it can be known that the BET specific surface area (20 m2 g−1) of 3.0F-Co3O4 was smaller than that (28 m2 g−1) of Co3O4(CP). The reason for this phenomenon can be attributed to the smaller pore volume of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst prepared by sol-gel method. Obviously, the specific surface area of the catalyst was not the determining factor for the excellent catalytic activity of 3.0F-Co3O4 compared with that of Co3O4(CP) and 0F-Co3O4. In order to understand the changes of catalyst microstructure more intuitively and thoroughly, the electron microscopy technology was employed. Fig. 3 A–C exhibited the SEM photos of Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts. It can be seen that three catalysts exhibited three different microscopic morphologies after 80,000 magnifications. The Co3O4(CP) presented an irregular spherical particle shape, while the 0F-Co3O4 exhibited a worm-like short rod structure. For the 3.0F-Co3O4, it showed more irregular and more agglomerated particles structure compared with the former two catalysts. In addition, from the EDS analysis (Fig. 3D) of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst, it can be seen that there were no elements other than Co and O (the trace amounts of C and Si originated from silicon wafers), which proved that the surfactant F127 had been completely removed in the calcination stage of the catalyst, and there was no residue. Fig. 4 gave the TEM and HR-TEM images of Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 to further and thoroughly explore the textural structure differences of the three catalysts. Fig. 4(A, a1 and a2) was the TEM and HRTEM images of Co3O4(CP) prepared by traditional co-precipitation method. It can be observed that the irregular spherical Co3O4 crystallite was in range of ∼15 - ∼45 nm with relatively smooth edges. The HR-TEM image (Fig. 4a2) showed that the Co3O4 crystallite in Co3O4(CP) exposed (111) and (311) crystal planes (the abundance is not known), which was consistence with that reported in the literature [32]. For the 0F-Co3O4 catalyst, it still presented a worm-like short rod structure with relatively smooth edges, as shown in the Fig. 4(B, b1 and b2). Except for the (111) crystal plane, more (422) crystal plane was also observed in Co3O4 crystallite of 0F-Co3O4 catalyst. Combined with the catalytic performance of 0F-Co3O4 catalyst shown in the Fig. 1, it can be speculated that the (422) crystal plane of Co3O4 is a low active crystal plane for the direct catalytic N2O decomposition. Fig. 4(C, c1 and c2) exhibited the TEM and HRTEM images of 3.0F-Co3O4 prepared by sol-gel method using F127 as surfactant. From the Fig. 4C and c1, it can be found that the Co3O4 crystallite in the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was more irregular, and the crystallite edges were more angular as marked by the dark blue dotted line in the Fig. 4c1, which was completely different from the former two catalysts. When a part in the Fig. 4c1 continues to be enlarged, it was shown in the Fig. 4c2. First of all, different from the 0F-Co3O4 catalyst, the Co3O4 crystallite in the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst exposed (111), (400) and (511) crystal planes (the abundance is not known) due to the effect of surfactant F127. The difference in exposed crystal planes may be the essential reason for the huge difference in the catalytic activities of the three catalysts. Moreover, by carefully observing the Fig. 4c2, it can also be found that different image contrasts exhibited the same interplanar spacing in the same direction, such as 1.54 Å for (400) and 2.05 Å for (511) crystal planes (marked by the dotted line in the figure). The interplanar spacing on the white dotted line in the vertical direction was 2.05 Å, and the (400) crystal plane was exposed, but in terms of the colour depth of the image, it was not like in the same horizontal plane, with high and low structural characteristics. This phenomenon indicated that the micro structure of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was not irregular spherical nanoparticles, but had a more complex surface structure. To verify the existence of this special structure, a more detailed analysis of the Fig. 4c2 was performed, as shown in the Fig. 5 . In the Fig. 5A, the region ① and ② were selected and enlarged, it can be seen that there was a clear sense of hierarchy at the edge of the Co3O4 crystallite as shown in the Fig. 5C and D. Continuing to enlarge the Fig. 5C and D to obtain the Fig. 5E and F, respectively. The Fig. 5E corresponded to the above exposed (511) crystal plane, and the Fig. 5F corresponded to the above exposed (400) crystal plane. It can be observed that although the directions of the edge lattice fringes were the same, representing the same crystal plane, the space height was different, and there was a certain drop. Through the analysis of the above results, the morphological characteristics of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst were very similar to the geographical “Yardang landform” (as shown in the Fig. 5B). The dark part in the middle represented the high raised part, and the transition part between deep and shallow was the “etching-like” morphology formed after being treated with surfactant F127. This unique microstructure of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst can contribute more defect sites, which can be employed as the active sites for the N2O decomposition. Moreover, in order to prove this special morphological structure of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst, HR-TEM images for more regions of the catalyst were also provided, as shown in the Fig. S2. Now, the structural changes that during the catalyst preparation process of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst using the sol-gel method (F127 as surfactant) can be speculated. During the preparation process, Pluronic F127 first dissolves in deionized water to form micelles, with the addition of Co ions and the gradual increase in temperature, the Co ions coordinate with the hydroxyl groups in F127 and uniformly disperse in the sol. The formation of gel and the drying process make Co ions immobilized around F127. By staged calcination, F127 was removed, and the (400) and (511) crystal planes of Co3O4 crystallite appeared due to the guidance of F127. At the same time, due to the steric-hindrance effect of F127, the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with “Yardang landform” structure was finally obtained. 3.3 Surface properties analysis of the catalysts In order to investigate the effect of F127 on the surface properties of the catalysts, Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 were characterized by XPS. Fig. 6 A showed the Co2p spectra of the above three catalysts. From the figure, it can be found that the binding energies of Co2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 of Co3O4(CP) catalyst were located at ∼780.6 eV and ∼795.9 eV respectively, which was in accordance with that reported in previous studies [12,15,31,33]. For the 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4, the binding energies of Co2p3/2 were located at ∼780.5 eV and ∼780.6 eV, which was hardly any obvious change compared with that of Co3O4(CP). The result indicated that the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst prepared by sol-gel method with F127 as surfactant does not weaken the strength of surface Co-O bond [12,20,31]. In order to further investigate the change of Co-O bond strength for the three catalysts, the FT-IR was performed and the results were listed in the Fig. S3. For the Co3O4(CP), two absorption bands due to the Co2+ vibration in the tetrahedral position and Co3+ vibration in the octahedral position were located at 665 and 574 cm−1, respectively [34]. It was reported that the red shift of the band is due to the Co-O bond weakening [32,35]. The band on 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 involving the Co3+ appeared at 574 and 571 cm−1, which was nearly the same compared with that for Co3O4(CP). The result of FT-IR was consistence with that of XPS. More in-depth, the Co2p3/2 XPS peak of the three catalysts was resolved into two peaks, which attributed to the Co2+ and Co3+ species on the catalyst surface, respectively [36]. Subsequently, the ratio of Co3+ and Co2+ were calculated according to the corresponding integrated peak areas. As presented in the Fig. 6A, the proportion of Co3+ on the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst surface reached 59.4% (Co3+/Co2+=1.46), which was much higher than that (47.9%, Co3+/Co2+=0.92) of 0F-Co3O4 and (47.1%, Co3+/Co2+=0.89) Co3O4(CP). Combined with the HR-TEM results, it can be speculated that the appearance of (400) and (511) crystal planes caused by the special effect of F127 surfactant on the structure of Co3O4 was the main reason for the higher surface Co3+ ratio of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst compared with Co3O4 (CP) and 0F-Co3O4. Abundant Co3+ species on the catalyst's surface can increase anion defects (oxygen vacancies), which is conducive to redox performance of the catalyst [37]. Above result can also be proved by O1s spectra. As shown in the Fig. 6B, the O1s spectra of the three catalysts can be deconvoluted into three peaks, which were assigned to Oα1 (surface adsorbed oxygen), Oα2 (adsorbed water or hydroxyl species) and Oβ (lattice oxygen), respectively [38]. The calculated ratios of surface adsorbed oxygen on the surface of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was 68.3%, which was much larger than that of 0F-Co3O4 (46.7%) and Co3O4(CP) (41.9%), respectively. It proved that more surface adsorbed oxygen species appeared on the surface of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst due to the presence of large amount of Co3+ species. More surface adsorbed oxygen species can roughly indicate 3.0F-Co3O4 possesses more oxygen vacancies. For the catalysing N2O decomposition reaction, oxygen vacancy was generally regarded as the active site by researchers [3,12,17–19,39]. Herein, it should be pointed out that the oxygen vacancy on the transitional metal oxide (contains Co3O4) catalyst surface refers to the sites which are capable of accepting an oxygen atom on the metal oxide surface, but not limited to the intrinsic deficiency of oxygen with two positive charges on the metal oxides. Hence, to determine the number of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, O2-TPD characterization of Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts was performed. As shown in the Fig. 7 , 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited much larger O2 desorption amounts (77.62 µmol g−1) than that of 0F-Co3O4 (26.38 µmol g−1) and Co3O4(CP) (11.64 µmol g−1) in the low temperature range (100–300 °C). Since one oxygen molecule can occupy two oxygen vacancies, the number of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the three catalysts was 155.24, 52.76 and 23.28 µmol g−1, respectively. The result proved that 3.0F-Co3O4 possessed a very large number of surface oxygen vacancies, which was the direct reason for the high activity of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst as shown in the Fig. 1. Meanwhile, the conclusion obtained from O2-TPD was approximately consistent with that obtained from O1s of XPS. Moreover, the surface oxygen vacancy density (active sites density) in the temperature range of 100–300 °C for the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst up to 7.62 µmol g−1 m−2, which was more than 9 times that of the Co3O4(CP) catalyst (only 0.82 µmol g−1 m−2). However, it should be noticed that although 0F-Co3O4 catalyst has a higher number of active sites than Co3O4(CP), it exhibited the worst catalytic performance amongst the three catalysts. It is well known that the deN2O performance of the catalyst is straightforward to the number of active sites and single active site reaction capacity. That is, the active sites on (422) crystal plane for the 0F-Co3O4 catalyst are low active for the direct catalytic N2O decomposition. According to the above characterization results, it can be considered that the higher surface oxygen vacancy density of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was correlated with the exposure of the (400) and (511) crystal planes, which also was the main reason for the high activity of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst for catalysing N2O decomposition. 3.4 Reaction kinetics study In order to analyse the structure-activity relationship of catalysts in multiple dimensions, the kinetic data of the reaction over the Co3O4(CP), 0F-Co3O4 and 3.0F-Co3O4 catalysts were calculated. The specific reaction rate (r) and reaction rate constants (k) of the three catalysts at different reaction temperatures were listed in the Table 2 . In general, the specific reaction rate (r) of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was much higher than that of 0F-Co3O4 and Co3O4(CP) catalyst at the same reaction temperature. At 300 °C, the reaction rate over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was 0.233 µmol s−1 g−1, which was about 8.6 times that of over the Co3O4(CP) catalyst and 29.1 times that of over the 0F-Co3O4 catalyst. According to the reaction rate constants, the activation energy (E a) of the three catalysts for the reaction could be calculated by Arrhenius equation, as shown in the Fig. 8 . The E a of the reaction over 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was 55.0 kJ mol−1, which was lower than that of Co3O4(CP) (78.5 kJ mol−1) and 0F-Co3O4 (83.0 kJ mol−1). In addition, according to the O2-TPD result of the three catalysts (as shown in the Fig. 7), the amount of effective active sites on the catalysts surface during the different temperature range can also be obtained. Combined with the reaction rate given in the Table 2, the TOF value of the three catalysts at different reaction temperatures can be calculated. As listed in the Table 2, it can be found that the TOF value of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was 1.50 ×10−3 s−1 at 300 °C, which was only slightly higher than that of Co3O4(CP) (1.16 × 10−3 s−1) and much higher than that of 0F-Co3O4 (1.52 × 10−4 s−1). The situation at 350 °C also exhibited the same trend, the 3.0F-Co3O4 and Co3O4(CP) catalysts nearly possessed the same TOF value. It intuitively proved that the catalytic ability of a single active site on the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst prepared by the sol-gel method with F127 as surfactant has not been improved compared with the Co3O4(CP) catalyst prepared by the traditional co-precipitation method. The higher number of active sites was regarded as the real reason for the high catalytic performance of 3.0F-Co3O4. Meanwhile, (400) and (511) crystal planes were considered as highly reactive crystal planes because they exposed more active sites than (111) and (311). Meanwhile, 0F-Co3O4 catalyst has the lowest TOF value amongst the three catalysts, which indicated that the active sites on (422) crystal plane of 0F-Co3O4 catalyst have low reactivity for the deN2O reaction. All in all, the considerable increment in catalytic activity of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst suggested that this preparation method was valuable. The performance of the prepared catalyst will be greatly improved, if enhance the capability of a single active site by appropriate method, such as the introduction of electronic additives [40,41]. 3.5 Reaction mechanism For the mechanism of deN2O reaction on the transition metal oxide-based catalysts, it had already been meticulously studied and reached an agreement by researchers [16,19,21]. In the process of catalytic N2O decomposition, N2O molecule is firstly adsorbed on the active sites (*) and quickly decomposed to N2 and adsorbed oxygen (O*). Then, the oxygen occupied active sites regenerate through Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal mechanism to complete the catalytic cycle: (I) N 2 O + * → * − O + N 2 (II) 2 * − O ↔ O 2 + 2 * ( L − H ) (III) N 2 O + * − O → O 2 + N 2 + * ( E − R ) In the process of catalytic N2O decomposition over the transition metal oxide-based catalysts, the regeneration of active sites is considered to be the speed control step, both increasing the number of active sites and improving the reaction capacity of a single active site can promote the catalytic performance of the aim catalysts. In this study, 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with “Yardang Landform” structure was prepared by the sol-gel method using F127 as surfactant. Due to the guidance of F127, the Co3O4 crystallites in 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst expose (400) and (511) crystal planes, which possess high active site density. A large number of surface-active sites greatly improve its catalytic performance compared with the traditional pure Co3O4(CP) catalyst prepared by co-precipitation. 3.6 Catalytic performance test The N2O emitted by human industrial production activities mainly comes from the production of chemical products such as nitric acid, adipic acid and the emission of vehicle exhaust after TWC (three ways catalyst) [3]. The impurities contained in these pollution sources, such as O2, H2O, CO2, SO2 and NO x , etc., which have a strong inhibitory effect on the low-temperature activity of the existing catalysts. Whether the catalyst has good resistance to the impurity gases plays a decisive role in whether it can be used in actual industrial production. Therefore, the resistance of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst to impurity gases exhausted from nitric acid plant was evaluated and compared with the Co3O4(CP) catalyst, as shown in the Fig. 9 . Fig. 9A showed the effect of the coexistence of 5 vol.% O2, 2 vol.% H2O, 100 ppmv NO, 5 vol.% O2 + 100 ppmv NO or 5 vol.% O2 + 2 vol.% H2O + 100 ppmv NO with 2000 ppmv N2O on the catalytic activity of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst for N2O decomposition. It can be found that the T 90 (temperature when N2O conversation achieves 90%) was 371 °C when no impurity gas was introduced into the system. When 100 ppmv NO, 5 vol.% O2 and 2 vol.% H2O was fed into the reaction system, the corresponding T 90 was 395, 399 and 402 °C, respectively. The increment was 24, 28 and 31 °C for NO, O2 and H2O, respectively. It means both NO, O2 and H2O inhibited the catalyst activity, but this inhibitory effect was relatively limited. In addition, when all of the impurity gases (5 vol.% O2, 100 ppmv NO and 2 vol.% H2O) were introduced into the reaction system, the T 90 increased to 433 °C with an increment of 62 °C. Under these reaction conditions, the N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst could still reach 68% at 400 °C, which is even higher than the Gd0.06Co catalyst that reported by our groups [31]. On the basis of the above results, it is not difficult to find that the catalyst has a good resistance to impurity gases. By contrast, the N2O conversion over the Co3O4(CP) catalyst in the case of coexistence of the above three impurity gases was only 28.7% at 400 °C, as shown in the Fig. 9B. In addition, the comparison of T 90 values between 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst and recently reported catalysts in literature for N2O decomposition under the ideal or submitted real reaction condition was listed in the Table S1 [13,19,20,22,42–47]. It can be found that although 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst did not add any additives, its catalytic performance was still excellent enough under the submitted real reaction condition. It means that its catalytic performance may be further improved after the modification of suitable additives. The N2O conversion changed with time on stream over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was examined at the specified reaction condition to investigate the stability of the catalyst. As shown in the Fig. 10 , the N2O conversion rate catalyst maintained at about 80% after first running for 11.5 h without any impurity gas at 350 °C. Subsequently, the addition of 5 vol.% O2 and 100 ppmv NO led to the N2O conversion rate immediately decreasing and stabilizing at ∼60% and ∼20%, respectively. Surprisingly, the N2O conversion rate did not decrease further when 2 vol.% H2O was continuously introduced. Considering that the surface-active sites of the catalyst were almost occupied by nitrogen oxide at lower reaction temperature, the subsequent water vapour could not continue to seize the remaining active sites. The N2O conversion remained stable at 20% during the next 2.5 h of reaction. After that, all impurity gases were cut off and the temperature was raised to 400 °C. It can be found that the N2O conversion rate quickly recovered to 100%. After continuing to run for 5 h, 5 vol.% O2, 100 ppmv NO and 2 vol.% H2O were introduced in sequence, and the N2O conversion rate decreased, but it maintained a fairly stable value (about 60% or more) for a long time. Finally, the cut off of all impurity gases still can make the N2O conversion revert to 100%. From the above phenomena, it can be summarized that the activity of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst is greatly influenced by nitrogen oxides at low temperature, while this situation disappeared at relatively higher reaction temperature. The activity of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was reversibly inhibited due to the competitive adsorption of O2, NO and H2O on the active sites, which can full recovery with the cut-off of impurity gases. Most importantly, the result indicated that the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited very satisfactory catalytic stability, although it possessed the special “Yardang Landform” micro structure. 4 Conclusions In summary, the highly efficient 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with “Yardang Landform” structure was prepared by the sol-gel method using F127 as surfactant. The N2O conversion over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was ∼80% at 350 °C, which was about 3.3 times that of the Co3O4(CP) catalyst prepared by traditional co-precipitation method. Textural structure and surface properties characterization indicated that although the specific surface area of the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was small and the Co-O bond was not very weak, its special “Yardang Landform” structure and the exposure of (400) and (511) crystal planes endow it plentiful active sites (up to 155.24 µmol g−1 in the range of 100–300 °C) for catalysing the N2O decomposition. At 300 °C, the reaction rate over the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was 0.233 µmol s−1 g−1, which was about 8.6 times that of the Co3O4(CP) catalyst. By calculating the activation energy, it was found that the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst also had a lower activation energy for the reaction. Most importantly, the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited good resistance to impurity gases and showed fairly stable catalytic performance (above 60%) in feed gas of 2000 ppmv N2O and 100 ppmv NO, 5 vol% O2 and 2 vol% H2O at 400 °C. coredata.dc:description: In this work, the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was synthesized by sol-gel method with the assistance of F127 and used for eliminating the N2O pollution from nitric acid plants. Research indicated that the presence of F127 in the preparation process endowed the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with unique “Yardang Landform” microstructure, which possessed a rich number of “edges and corners”. The unique microstructure enables the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst to mainly expose highly active (400) and (511) crystal planes. Based on this unique microstructure, the surface active site density for 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst was 7.62 µmol g−1 m2, which was about 9 times that of Co3O4(CP) catalyst prepared by traditional co-precipitation method. In addition, the 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst demonstrated high catalytic activity and stability for the reaction in presence of impurity gases. For example, the catalyst can maintain a conversion of more than 60% for N2O at least 10 h in the feed stream of 2000 ppmv N2O/Ar with 5 vol% O2, 100 ppmv NO and 2 vol% H2O at 400 °C and GHSV = 20,000 h−1.
coredata.dc:title: The preparation of 3.0F-Co3O4 catalyst with “Yardang Landform” structure and its performance for catalyzing N2O decomposition
